title: Incas (Tawantinsuyu)
common: In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

Names

Although we refer to the ancient empire today as the "Inca empire", the Inca people did not use this term. They called themselves Tahuantinsuyu, meaning "Tierra de los Cuatro Cuartos". In addition to regional names, the titles used for their leaders are not widely known. For simplicity, we will use the terms "king" and "kings", along with the title Sapa (Cartwright, M., ; Harris, K. R., , pp. 55).

Periods

Determining the precise beginnings of this civilization is challenging due to inconsistent dates provided by chroniclers. Early historical studies assigned somewhat arbitrary timeframes. Generally, the most significant events are believed to have occurred between the 15th and early 16th centuries, according to the Gregorian calendar. However, some chronicles place the empire's founding as early as the 13th century (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 427 - 428 ; Barker, R., , pp. 8 - 12).

Dr. Robert Barker raises an intriguing point: the twelve generations of Inca rulers may have a connection to the twelve tribes of Israel, suggesting the possibility of additional generations. Based on this theory, we propose dividing the Inca kings (Sapa) into two distinct groups: those with long reigns, for whom there is little concrete evidence, are considered descendants of Manco Cápac; while those with shorter, better-documented reigns are classified as descendants of Pachacutec (Barker, R., , pp. 12 ; Eileen M. Crimmins, ; Barker, R., , pp. 12).

The absence of a formal writing system among the Inca has long been a major challenge in reconstructing their history. However, recent scientific advances may change this understanding. New research suggests that the (quipus) system of knots, traditionally viewed as a tool for counting, may have contained more complex information, potentially serving as a form of writing (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008 ; Hyland, S., ; Cartwright, M., ; Laurencich Minelli, L., ; Urton, G., ; Moras, Roberto, ; Moras, Roberto, ).
prerequisites: There are no additional prerequisites to understand this text.

families.name: Descendants of Manco Capac and Mama Ocllo (Hurin dynasty)
history: We begin this study with a reflection on origins:

?
Reflection 1: On Origins

When Spanish chroniclers described the history of an unfamiliar people, did they interpret events through the lens of their own culture? Additionally, could Inca narratives have been shaped by beliefs, as happens in many other cultures?

people.name: Manco Capac
history: The origin of the Inca people is often associated with the couple Manco Capac and Mama Ocllo, according to various chronicles. However, the accounts of their origin differ and, at times, contradict each other. Some sources suggest they emerged from a crater, where they also found gold used in their clothing, while others claim they came from Lake Titicaca. Despite these discrepancies, Manco Capac and Mama Ocllo are typically credited with founding the city of Cuzco around the 13th century, according to the Gregorian calendar (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 9 - 12 ; Barker, R., , pp. 137 - 140 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 3).

marriages.name: Mama Ocllo
history: According to ancient chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 10 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 3).

children.name: Sinchi Roca
history: According to ancient chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 16 ; Barker, R., , pp. 140 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 6).

people.name: Sinchi Roca
history: Sinchi Roca is believed to have been the second king (Sapa), credited with the introduction of the terrace farming system used in agriculture. Additionally, it is said that he engaged in conflicts with various local groups during his reign (Barker, R., , pp. 140).

Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, an indigenous chronicler, made a reference when describing Sinchi Roca and his wife, stating that they were the parents of Jesus Christ. This assertion leads us to another reflection (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 123 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 89 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 6 - 7):

?
Reflection 2: On Relationships

Is this claim simply an error by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala? Or is it possible to identify some parallel between this statement and the genealogy of Jesus Christ as presented in the Gospel of Saint Matthew (Mateus, Cap. 1:6-16)?

It is tempting to quickly label something as right or wrong and thus close the matter. However, there is often more information to consider in such reflections. Could you propose other possible hypotheses?

Mathematics and Biology in History

We are comparing different accounts in which a person is said to have two different sets of parents. Although the authorship and exact date of the Gospel of Matthew are unknown, it was cited in two early church texts from the 2nd century, according to the Gregorian calendar (Judd, Frank F. Jr., , pp. 129). In contrast, the Incas mentioned by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala would have lived in the 13th century. This creates a gap of nearly 1300 years between the figures mentioned. As it is not possible for children to be older than their parents, the reference by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala likely holds a deeper or symbolic meaning.

marriages.name: Mama Coca
history: According to ancient chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 17).

children.name: Lloque Yupanqui
history: According to ancient chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 17).

children.name: Mama Cora Ocllo Coya
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 89 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 65 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

children.name: Jesus
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, one passage presents this information, while another mentions data that aligns with the Gospels (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 87, 123 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 62, 89 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

people.name: Lloque Yupanqui
history: Lloque Yupanqui's reign was marked by various rebellions. According to some accounts, during his rule, a market was established that allowed trade with their enemies (Barker, R., , pp. 141 - 142).
The chronicler Juan Betanzos reported that, at birth, Lloque Yupanqui already had teeth and the ability to walk, comparing him to the legendary figure Merlin (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 17).

marriages.name: Mama Cora Ocllo Coya
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 97 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 71 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

children.name: Mayta Capac
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 97 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 71 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

people.name: Mayta Capac
history: Mayta Capac is believed to have been responsible for significantly expanding the empire's route network and is remembered as a great warrior (Barker, R., , pp. 142 - 143).
He is considered the last of four generations associated with improbable events, which is why anthropologist Susan A. Niles classifies them as mythological figures (Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56)

marriages.name: Chimbo Mama Yachi
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 99 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 71 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

children.name: Capac Yupanqui
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 99 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 74 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 7).

people.name: Capac Yupanqui
history: We begin by noting that anthropologist Susan A. Niles classifies the possible reign of Capac Yupanqui as unknown (Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56). However, it is believed that he was the last ruler of the Hurin dynasty. After his death, a civil war erupted between factions associated with his wives, Cusi Chimbo and Cusi Hilpay, an Ayarmaca from Anta, known enemies of the Incas. This conflict led to the death of his successor, Quispe Yupanqui, and ultimately brought another of Capac Yupanqui's sons, Inca Roca, to power (Barker, R., , pp. 143 - 144).

marriages.name: Cusi Hilpay
history: According to researches (Barker, R., , pp. 143 - 144 ; Cahill, David, , pp. 15).

marriages.name: Cusi Chimbo
history: According to researches and chronicle (Barker, R., , pp. 143 - 144 ; Cahill, David, , pp. 15 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 99 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 71).

marriages.name: Unknown
history: The sources are unclear about which wife was the mother of the mentioned sons. Although it is possible to speculate, we prefer to exercise caution and acknowledge the uncertainty by referencing an unnamed spouse

families.name: Descendants of Inca Roca (Hanan Dynasty)
history: After the murder of the preferred successor, Inca Roca was brought to power by the victorious factions, marking the beginning of the Hanan dynasty (Barker, R., , pp. 144).

people.name: Inca Roca
history: Various studies attribute significant local developments to the reign of Inca Roca, including the establishment of hydraulic systems, urbanization projects, and the construction of new roads (Barker, R., , pp. 144 - 145).

marriages.name: Cusi Chimbo
history: Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala mentions her as Inca Roca's wife, while other chronicles and more recent research refer to her as the mother of Inca Roca (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 131 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 96).

marriages.name: Unknown
history: The discrepancies between chronicles led to the creation of this hypothetical figure.

children.name: Yahuar Huacac
history: As recorded in a chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 18).

people.name: Yahuar Huacac
history: There are significant discrepancies in the historical accounts of Yahuar Huacac's reign, making it difficult to accurately attribute specific events to him. One notable event often highlighted is the Incan victory over the Chancas, which led to the dispersion of their enemies (Barker, R., , pp. 145 - 148).

marriages.name: Ipauaco Mamachi Coya
history: According to ancient chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 133 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 96)

children.name: Viracocha
history: According to ancient chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], pp. 18)

people.name: Viracocha
history: Viracocha was probably the first government to expand the territory beyond Cuzco borders, ruling the civilization until the year (Barker, R., , pp. 145 - 148 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 269 - 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79). This year, after to show some weakness, he left Cuzco, but his son was kept with their generals to defend the city of the last Chancas attack (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 427).
Juan Betanzos gives a deeep report for this king (Sapa) when we compare with the previous (Betanzos, Juan, [ ()], 18 - 26).

marriages.name: Mama Yunto Cayan Coya
history: According to an ancient chronicle (Rowe, J. H., , pp. 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107, 135 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79, 100).

children.name: Titu Cusi Yupanki (Pachacuti)
history: Based on various studies and the chronicles of Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 427 ; Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 267, 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79).

children.name: Urcon Inca
history: According to the research of John H. Rowe and an ancient Chronicle (Rowe, J. H., , pp. 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79).

children.name: Mama Anauarque
history: According to ancient chronicle (Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79).

families.name: Descendants of Viracocha
history: The year , proposed by John H. Rowe as the end of Viracocha's rule and the beginning of his sons' reigns, might be considered somewhat arbitrary, as certain rulers may have been omitted from the historical record. Dr. Robert Barker emphasizes that it is only from Viracocha onward that we have the "real history" of the Incas (Barker, R., , pp. 26 - 43).

?
Reflection 3: On Periods of Time

Considering the possible absence of a written system with exact dates, how could Dr. Robert Barker confirm that the years presented by John H. Rowe are incorrect?

Sciences do not work in isolation; instead, the integration of knowledge from different fields is essential for understanding historical events with greater accuracy. To support his conclusions, Dr. Barker used Carbon-14 dating in Inca archaeological sites (Barker, R., , pp. 123 - 133).

Mathematics, Biology, Physics, and Chemistry in History

All living organisms are composed of cells, which in turn are made of atoms. An atom is defined by its number of protons, also known as its atomic number. However, the number of neutrons is also crucial for this analysis. For example, hydrogen atoms can have 0, 1, or 2 neutrons, resulting in different isotopes of the same element (Herzog, G. F., ).

How does this relate to Inca history? The carbon atom has an isotope called Carbon-14, which contains six protons and eight neutrons. Plants absorb this isotope, and when animals — including humans — consume the plants, they absorb Carbon-14 into their bodies as well. Over time, the Carbon-14 in organisms decays, turning into another element. Thanks to modern knowledge of the decay process, scientists can measure the remaining amount of Carbon-14 in an object to determine its age with relative precision (Koppes, S., Lerner, L., ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ).

Dr. Robert Barker presented charts showing Carbon-14 measurements taken at archaeological sites such as Farfán, Cerro Azul, Pachacamac, and Chancay. These results demonstrated that Rowe’s original hypothesis, proposed in was an "invalid fact" (Barker, R., , pp. 126 - 133)

people.name: Urcon Inca
history: According to John H. Rowe, Urcon Inca was Viracocha's favored son for succession, while Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala identifies Titu Cusi Yupanki as the firstborn and rightful heir. Dr. Robert Barker's thesis suggests that Urcon was crowned king (SapaRowe, J. H., , pp. 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 79 ; Barker, R., , pp. 151 - 152).

people.name: Mama Anauarque
history: Her marriage is cited by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and Phlomena Gebran (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 - 109, 137 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 82, 100 ; Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8). However, Tom Zuidema refers to her as a "mythical" figure (Zuidema, Tom, , pp. 49).
Her descendants are detailed in the section corresponding to her husband, who was also her brother.

marriages.name: Titu Cusi Yupanki (Pachacuti)
history: According to various researchers and the chronicle of Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8 ; Zuidema, Tom, , pp. 49 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 107 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 77 - 82).

people.name: Titu Cusi Yupanki (Pachacuti)
history: Cabello Balboa arbitrarily stated that Titu Cusi Yupanki achieved victory against his enemies, the Chancas, between and (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428). While there are doubts about the exact chronology, there is a consensus that the Inca Empire’s splendor began with him (Barker, R., , pp. 149 - 150).

After his victory over the Chancas, Titu Cusi Yupanki conquered other neighboring ethnic groups and eventually subjugated the Ayamarca. Following the death of his brother Urco, he ascended to the throne as king (Sapa), adopting the name Pachacuti (Barker, R., , pp. 153).

The expansion of the Inca Empire was achieved with the help of his brothers, while Pachacuti focused on rebuilding Cuzco (Barker, R., , pp. 154 - 155 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 270, 271 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428).
Figure 1: Statue of Pachacuti in the city of Cuzco (Sitios del Patrimonio Mundial del Perú). Photo taken on , during a visit to the city.

marriages.name: Mama Anauarque
history: According to various researchers and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, Pachacuti is said to have married his own sister (Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8 ; Zuidema, Tom, , pp. 49 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 109 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 79).

children.name: Yamque Yupanqui
history: According to different chronciles (Barker, R., , pp. 159, 161 ).

children.name: Tupak Yupanki
history: According to several researchers and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428 ; Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 267, 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 109, 137 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 79, 100).
On the other hand, Dr. Robert Barker, when analyzing the chronicles, argues that he would not be his son, but rather his great-grandson (Barker, R., , pp. 155 - 159 ).

children.name: Amaro Topa
history: According to different chronicles (Barker, R., , pp. 155 - 159 ).

people.name: Amaro Topa
history: It is possible that there was at least one more generation between Pachacuti and Tupac Yupanqui. His existence can be inferred from the conquests in the region known today as Bolivia, as mentioned in Betanzos' chronicle. Furthermore, Bartolomé de las Casas suggests that Amaro Topa was Pachacuti’s preferred successor, an assertion also supported by Juan de Santa Cruz Pachacuti Yamqui Salcamaygua. Dr. Robert Barker also cites two additional chronicles that refer to him (Barker, R., , pp. 157 - 161 ).

marriages.name: Curi Ocllo
history: According to a chronicle and researches (Barker, R., , pp. 160 - 161 ).

people.name: Yamque Yupanqui
history: The information presented by Betanzos, along with his mention at the beginning of the chronicle, suggests the possible existence of at least one coregency. Betanzos also reports that Yamque Yupanqui reached Ecuador (Barker, R., , pp. 161 - 164 ; Betanzos, Juan, [ ()]).

people.name: Tupak Yupanki
history: Tupak Yupanki was a renowned warrior, responsible for continuing the expansion of the Empire, like his father (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 111 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 82 ; Raffino, Rodolfo & Stehberg, Rubén, , pp. 168 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 271 - 272 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428 ; Barker, R., , pp. 164 - 167 ).

Tupak Yupanki created an extensive social organization, dividing the population into groups of ten (chunga), hundreds (pachacaguaranga) of men. He initially had the close support of his brother, Topac Capac, but his brother eventually rebelled against him (Barker, R., , pp. 167 - 168).

In recent decades, various studies have suggested that Tupak Yupanki may have traveled to Oceania. We recommend reviewing the work of Dr. Eiffel Eduardo Ramírez Avilés, which explores both the historical context and the current understanding of this possible journey (Ramírez Avilés, Eiffel Eduardo, , pp. 37 - 41).

marriages.name: Ocllo Coya
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 111, 139 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 82, 100 - 103).

children.name: Huayna Capac (Guayanacaba)
history: According to several studies (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428 ; Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 267, 270 ; Barker, R., , pp. 167 - 168 ).

people.name: Huayna Capac (Guayanacaba)
history: Huayna Capac is described in detail by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 111 - 114 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 82 - 83). During his reign, the empire continued its expansion, likely reaching what is now Argentina (Raffino, Rodolfo & Stehberg, Rubén, , pp. 168 ; Rowe, J. H., , pp. 272 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428).

Pedro Sánchez de Hoz, who accompanied Pizarro in the early years of colonization, provides important information about Huayna Capac, although by that time he was no longer in power (De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 125 - 126, 135 - 138, 142 - 143). When describing the city of Cusco, Sánchez de Hoz mentioned the city walls, stating, "The Spaniards who see them say that neither the Segovia bridge nor the constructions of Hercules or the Romans are as impressive as these" (Los Españoles que la ven dicen, que ni el puente de Segovia, ni otro de los edificios hicieron Hércules ni los Romanos, no son cosas tan dignas de verse como esto.) (De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 127).

The end of Huayna Capac’s reign is uncertain, with the possibility that he died from a disease brought by the colonizers (Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 142 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 427 - 428 ; Barker, R., , pp. 167 - 168 ).

marriages.name: Mama Ocllo
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and the glossary in the chronicle by Pedro Sánchez de Hoz (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 114 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 83 - 85 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 142).

marriages.name: Paccha
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and the glossary in the chronicle by Pedro Sánchez de Hoz (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 114 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 83 - 85 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 142).

children.name: Huascar
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and the glossary in the chronicle by Pedro Sánchez de Hoz (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 114 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 83 - 85 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 142).

children.name: Atahualpa
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and the glossary in the chronicle by Pedro Sánchez de Hoz (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 114 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 83 - 85 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., , pp. 142).

people.name: Huascar
history: Huascar led his people for a brief period, sharing power with his brother Atahualpa during a tumultuous civil war (Niles, Susan A., , pp. 56 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428 - 429). He passed away without leaving any heirs (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 116 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 83 - 85).

marriages.name: Chuquillanto Coya
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, , pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 116 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 85 ).

people.name: Atahualpa
history: Atahualpa was the last emperor (Sapa) of the Inca Empire. After winning the civil war against his brother Huascar, he committed brutal acts, but was eventually captured and executed by Spanish colonizers in Cajamarca, an event known as the "Cajamarca Ambush" (Celada de Cajamarca) (Lumbreras, Luis G., , pp. 428 - 429 ; Academia Play, , 01:25 ; Barker, R., , pp. 170 ).

exercise_v2.question: Is the Inca civilization well documented?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: It is still not possible to confirm definitively that the Inca civilization had a writing system, which makes it difficult to interpret them in the traditional way.

exercise_v2.question: Are the earliest generations of the Inca the most uncertain?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The accounts of the earliest Inca generations are filled with allegories, metaphors, and improbable events, strongly suggesting that they may be largely mythological.

exercise_v2.question: Did the Inca have only one dynasty?
Were the periods attributed to the Inca before the discovery of Carbon-14 confirmed by this method?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The timelines previously attributed to the Inca are questionable, as they propose impossible lifespans for the early generations. Additionally, there are notable discrepancies between different chronicles. Carbon-14 dating results suggest that the civilization might be much older than originally believed.

exercise_v2.question: Was the Inca expansion peaceful, since Indigenous people did not engage in wars?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: There is no evidence to support the claim that Indigenous people, including the Incas, never engaged in war. On the contrary, the chronicles describe the Incas fighting various battles to expand their territory from Cuzco, as well as engaging in multiple civil wars.
